refined_goal: Build SATNET-Bridge: a software-defined gateway that lets any PC LAN talk to a satellite network without proprietary modems, by combining a TUN/TAP virtual NIC, a Delay/Disruption Tolerant overlay (BPv7/LTP) in Go, and an SDR-backed C++ PHY with adaptive FEC/modulation. A React-based 3D pass planner drives antenna pointing from live TLEs. Success criteria: (1) seamless IP reachability to a satellite ground peer with 95%+ delivery ratio under 200–800 ms one-way delay; (2) sustained 2–10 Mbps burst throughput on LEO passes with sub-2 s re-acquisition after loss; (3) automatic pass-aware routing and prefetch with >70% cache-hit during outages; (4) setup in <30 minutes using COTS SDR + rotator. Why it matters: it turns satellite links from exotic, manual, and vendor-locked into programmable, pass-aware IP paths that any developer can extend, simulate, or deploy in the field.
repository_synergy:
THE INSIGHT: Treat a satellite link not as a fragile RF tunnel but as a time-varying, programmable network function. Then give it a developer-grade control plane (Go), a learnable visualization (React Three Fiber), and data-driven link prediction (TLE + public datasets). The illicit bridge is to repurpose UI/animation and algorithm repos as live, operational link controllers rather than mere front-ends or academic code.

THE STORY — Why these repos:
- avelino/awesome-go is not code; it’s a map to the Go networking ecosystem: QUIC (quic-go), WebRTC (pion), DTN projects, io_uring wrappers, high-perf telemetry. It accelerates a production-grade gateway.
- pmndrs/react-three-fiber + react-spring usually power 3D web scenes. Here they become a pass-aware network control room: Earth, satellites, your dish, and time-animated contact windows. Operators intuitively steer policies by dragging orbits and waypoints.
- academic/awesome-datascience and awesomedata/awesome-public-datasets seed the ML and data ingestion stack: ionospheric TEC maps, Kp/Ap indices, solar flux, atmospheric models—feeding adaptive coding and pass risk scores.
- RenanRB/satellities_TLE is the pragmatic TLE fetcher/glue to keep ephemerides fresh (Celestrak, etc.), powering both pointing and scheduling.
- TheAlgorithms/C-Plus-Plus provides battle-tested algorithmic building blocks—encoders/decoders, transforms, bit ops—to stand up a portable FEC/modem prototype in C++ for SDR PHY, before swapping in vendor DSP.
- vsouza/awesome-ios curates AR, BLE, and sensor frameworks; repurposed to build a field alignment app that pairs a phone’s camera/IMU with the 3D scene for one-person dish setup.

THE SYNERGY: Networking-in-Go gives us clean concurrency for BPv7, QUIC aggregation, and custody transfer. The React 3D stack elevates link control from ‘config files and CRON’ to a kinetic understanding of time-varying geometry. TLE + public datasets power a predictive controller that schedules prefetch, adjusts FEC rates, and shifts application behavior with the orbit, not just with SNR. The C++ algorithms bridge PC IP to over‑the‑air SDR frames with resilience knobs usually buried in vendor modems.

THE INNOVATION: By fusing UI animation, data science curation, and low-level algorithms, we get a satellite gateway that is natively pass-aware, delay-tolerant, and developer-extensible. You don’t just tunnel IP; you orchestrate time, physics, and policy in one loop. The illicit connection is turning a web animation framework into the operator HMI and control surface for RF scheduling, and using a general algorithms repo as the seed to synthesize a pragmatic SDR PHY—closing the loop between orbit prediction, UI intent, and on-air frames.
technical_architecture:
Components and data flow:
1) SatBridge Daemon (Go)
- Interfaces: TUN/TAP virtual NIC to capture/emit IP packets; gRPC/Protobuf for inter-process control; WebSocket for UI.
- Protocols: BPv7 over LTP for disruption tolerance; QUIC aggregation for interactive flows; optional WebRTC DataChannels (pion) for NAT traversal/relay to remote ground gateway.
- Functions: Flow classifier marks traffic for DTN vs QUIC-RTC; bundle slicing aligned to FEC codeword boundaries; custody transfer; pass-aware prefetch/caching; keying/TLS.

2) Ephemeris & Link Planner (Python)
- Uses RenanRB/satellities_TLE to pull TLEs periodically; computes contact windows, az/el, range rate, Doppler, elevation masks.
- Ingests public datasets (TEC, Kp) to score link risk and recommend MCS/FEC; exports a rolling ‘contact plan’ to the Daemon.

3) Radio PHY (C++/SDR)
- SDR HAL via SoapySDR/UHD; framed burst modulator (BPSK/QPSK/π/4-QPSK to start); Doppler pre-comp.
- FEC: convolutional/Viterbi, RS/Hamming seeds implemented using patterns from TheAlgorithms/C-Plus-Plus; pluggable LDPC later.
- Host link via shared-memory ring or AF_XDP/DPDK for zero-copy frames; gRPC ‘txFrame/rxFrame’ control.

4) Control & Visualization (TypeScript/React)
- react-three-fiber renders Earth, satellite ephemerides, ground stations, and pass cones; react-spring animates time scrubbing, handover previews.
- Operators tune policies (e.g., ‘increase FEC on low elevation’), schedule prefetch, and bless contact plans; events pushed to Daemon via WebSocket.

5) Field Alignment (iOS optional)
- AR-guided pointing: from vsouza/awesome-ios curation, leverage ARKit + BLE to align a rotator to computed az/el; sends alignment telemetry to UI.

Key challenges & solutions:
- Variable delay/jitter: Use BPv7 custody transfer and forward error correction; aggregate small flows over QUIC datagrams with loss-aware pacing (quic-go).
- Handover/outage: Pass-aware caching and prefetch; 0-RTT session resumption on re-acquisition; priority queues favor control bundles.
- Zero copy & CPU: Use io_uring/AF_XDP for TUN reads/writes; shared memory rings between Go Daemon and C++ PHY; pre-allocate bundle slabs sized to FEC codewords.
- Doppler & burst timing: Planner provides per-second Doppler profile; PHY schedules bursts with pre-compensation; timestamping via PTP if available.

APIs (sketch):
- dtn.SendBundle(BundleMeta, bytes) -> Ack
- phy.TxFrame(FrameMeta{mcs, fec_rate, center_freq, doppler_ppm}, bytes) -> Status
- planner.ContactPlan(now..now+48h) -> list<ContactWindow>
- ui.Subscribe(‘telemetry’) -> stream<State>

Performance considerations:
- Packet coalescing into bundles sized for optimal FEC blocks reduces over-the-air overhead.
- Hybrid mode: real-time flows via QUIC-RTC during good link; bulk via DTN in background.
- Scheduling: contact plan drives transmit windowing; application hints (e.g., HTTP prefetch) executed just-in-time before LOS.

Integration pattern: The Go Daemon is the hub. Python planner writes to it; C++ PHY exposes gRPC; React UI subscribes to both. ‘awesome-go’ curates production-grade libs; TLE + datasets drive predictive adaptation; Algorithms/C++ seeds the physical framing to keep the stack fully open.
expected_impact:
Use cases uniquely enabled:
1) Pop-up research camp: A laptop + SDR + small rotator becomes a pass-aware IP gateway. Scientists sync GIS layers minutes before a pass, then DTN trickles results back while offline.
2) Maritime weather and routing: Vessel PC routes only GRIB/weather services over the sat overlay. The planner prefetches forecasts before low-elevation fades; QUIC-RTC keeps bridge telemetry live.
3) Disaster response Wi-Fi bubble: Mesh APs uplink via SATNET-Bridge. Static content is prepositioned; live SITREPs ride QUIC during high-elevation windows; DTN assures delivery with custody receipts.
4) University cubesat lab: Students simulate and then operate a link: the 3D UI visualizes real passes; the C++ PHY runs on a Lime/USRP; DTN experiments happen without buying a proprietary modem.
5) Remote industrial monitoring: Edge PCs batch sensor deltas as DTN bundles; planner avoids low-geometry periods; anomalies punch through via prioritized QUIC datagrams.
6) Amateur satellite IP experiments: Wrap IP microflows into AX.25-like bursts with strong FEC on legal bands; the UI schedules beacons and downlinks responsibly.
7) Edge CDN prefetch: Before a pass, the gateway pulls user-specific content so offline browsing feels native.

Scalability/extensibility:
- Multi-sat, multi-ground: the planner merges windows; the Daemon balances bundles by policy.
- Pluggable PHY: swap SDR or certified modems as available; keep BPv7/QUIC layers unchanged.

Limitations & mitigations:
- Regulatory/spectrum constraints: operate only on licensed/authorized bands; provide a ‘simulation mode’ and ‘loopback over UDP’ for development.
- Throughput bounds: SDR and small dishes limit MCS; mitigate with smart prefetch/caching and adaptive FEC.
- Antenna pointing complexity: AR-guided iOS app and 3D UI reduce setup friction; store alignment profiles for reuse.
innovation_analysis:
Innovation score: 8.7/10. The novelty is reframing satellite access as a pass-aware, DTN-QUIC programmable overlay with a 3D operational UI—built by recombining curation repos, UI animation, TLE tooling, and generic algorithms into an end-to-end system.

Immediate next steps:
- MVP: Go Daemon with TUN/TAP -> BPv7 bundling -> UDP loopback PHY; integrate TLE planner for contact gating; React Three Fiber UI to visualize schedules.
- Add quic-go aggregation path; instrument metrics; simulate outages.
- C++ PHY stub with FEC framing (TheAlgorithms seeds), then link to an SDR.

Key metrics:
- Bundle delivery ratio, goodput vs SNR, re-acquisition time, CPU per Mbps, cache hit-rate during outage, pointing error vs UI estimate.

Essential tools:
- Go (quic-go, pion/webrtc), Protobuf/gRPC, io_uring/AF_XDP, C++17/CMake, SoapySDR/UHD, Python (TLE + numpy), React/TypeScript (react-three-fiber, react-spring).

sources.name: pmndrs/react-spring
sources.readme_snippet:
Special thanks to:

Warp is built for coding with multiple AI agents



react-spring

A spring-physics first animation library
giving you flexible tools to confidently cast your ideas



`react-spring` is a cross-platform spring-physics first animation library. It's as simple as: ```jsx const styles = useSpring({ from: { opacity: 0 }, to: { opacity: 1 } }) ``` Just a small bit about us: - **Cross-Platform**: We support `react-dom`, `react-native`, `react-three-fiber`, `react-konva` & `react-zdog`. - **Versatile**: Be declarative with your animations or if you prefer, imperative. - **Spring-Physics First**: By default animation use springs for fluid interactivity, but we support durations with easings as well. There's a lot more to be had! Give it a try and find out. ## Getting Started ### ⚡️

[![Version](https://img.shields.io/npm/v/@react-three/fiber?style=flat&colorA=000000&colorB=000000)](https://npmjs.com/package/@react-three/fiber) [![Downloads](https://img.shields.io/npm/dt/@react-three/fiber.svg?style=flat&colorA=000000&colorB=000000)](https://npmjs.com/package/@react-three/fiber) [![Twitter](https://img.shields.io/twitter/follow/pmndrs?label=%40pmndrs&style=flat&colorA=000000&colorB=000000&logo=twitter&logoColor=000000)](https://twitter.com/pmndrs) [![Discord](https://img.shields.io/discord/740090768164651008?style=flat&colorA=000000&colorB=000000&label=discord&logo=discord&logoColor=000000)](https://discord.gg/ZZjjNvJ) [![Open Collective](https://img.shields.io/opencollective/all/react-three-fiber?style=flat&colorA=000000&colorB=000000)](https://opencollective.com/react-three-fiber) [![ETH](https://img.shields.io/badge/ETH-f5f5f5?style=flat&colorA=000000&colorB=000000)](https://blockchain.com/eth/address/0x6E3f79Ea1d0dcedeb33D3fC6c34d2B1f156F2682) [![BTC](https://img.shields.io/badge/BTC-f5f5f5?style=flat&colorA=000000&colorB=000000)](https://blockchain.com/btc/address/36fuguTPxGCNnYZSRdgdh6Ea94brCAjMbH) react-three-fiber is a React renderer for threejs. Build your scene declaratively with re-usable, self-contained components that react to state, are readily interactive and can participate in React's ecosystem. ```bash npm install three @types/three @react-three/fiber ``` > [!WARNING] > Three-fiber is a React renderer, it must pair with a major version of React, just like react-dom, react-native, etc. @react-three/fiber@8 pairs with react@18, @react-three/fiber@9 pairs with react@19. --- #### Does it have limitations? None. Everything that works in Threejs will work here without exception. #### Is it slower than plain Threejs

sources.name: RenanRB/satellities_TLE
sources.readme_snippet:
# Satellite TLE Data Generator

The Satellite TLE Data Generator is a Python script that retrieves satellite information from Celestrak website and generates JSON files for easy usage. By simply calling the `data/gps_tles.json` file provided in this project, users will have access to all available GPS TLEs (Two-Line Elements) at the given moment. This project automatically updates the satellite data on a daily basis.

## Features

- Retrieves satellite information from Celestrak website.
- Generates JSON files containing TLE data for GPS satellites.
- Daily automatic updates to ensure data accuracy.

## Use case

I currently use this project to feed the data used in my application: https://droneweather.xyz/, I use the library: https://github.com/jhermsmeier/node-tle to read the data and build the necessary information for presentation.

Awesome Public Datasets
=======================

.. image:: https://cdn.rawgit.com/sindresorhus/awesome/d7305f38d29fed78fa85652e3a63e154dd8e8829/media/badge.svg
   :alt: Awesome
   :target: https://github.com/sindresorhus/awesome

This is a list of `topic-centric public data sources <https://github.com/awesomedata/awesome-public-datasets>`_
in high quality. They are collected and tidied from blogs, answers, and user responses.
Most of the data sets listed below are free, however, some are not.
This project was incubated at `OMNILab <https://github.com/OMNILab>`_, Shanghai Jiao Tong University during Xiaming Chen's Ph.D. studies.
OMNILab is now part of the `BaiYuLan Open AI community <https://github.com/Bai-Yu-Lan>`_.
Other amazingly awesome lists can be found in `sindresorhus's awesome <https://github.com/sindresorhus/awesome>`_ list.

sources.name: TheAlgorithms/C-Plus-Plus
sources.readme_snippet:
# The Algorithms - C++ # {#mainpage}

<!-- the suffix in the above line is required for doxygen to consider this as the index page of the generated documentation site -->

[![Gitpod Ready-to-Code](https://img.shields.io/badge/Gitpod-Ready--to--Code-blue?logo=gitpod)](https://gitpod.io/#https://github.com/TheAlgorithms/C-Plus-Plus)
[![CodeQL CI](https://github.com/TheAlgorithms/C-Plus-Plus/actions/workflows/codeql.yml/badge.svg)](https://github.com/TheAlgorithms/C-Plus-Plus/actions/workflows/codeql.yml)
[![Gitter chat](https://img.shields.io/badge/Chat-Gitter-ff69b4.svg?label=Chat&logo=gitter&style=flat-square)](https://gitter.im/TheAlgorithms)

## Overview

This repository is a collection of open-source implementation of a variety of algorithms implemented in C++ and licensed under [MIT License](https://github.com/TheAlgorithms/C-Plus-Plus/blob/master/LICENSE). These algorithms span a variety of topics from computer science, mathematics and statistics, da

discovery_params.goal: Find a solution to make a PC internet network communicate directly with a satellite network

blueprint.title: GitRecombo — Out‑of‑Scale Blueprint
blueprint.summary: Recombination of recent GitHub innovations with long-tail exploration, health/reputation signals, and optional semantic relevance.
blueprint.architecture_ascii:
[1] avelino/awesome-go  →  [2] pmndrs/react-spring  →  [3] pmndrs/react-three-fiber  →  [4] academic/awesome-datascience  →  [5] RenanRB/satellities_TLE  →  [6] awesomedata/awesome-public-datasets  →  [7] vsouza/awesome-ios  →  [8] TheAlgorithms/C-Plus-Plus
            ↓
        [ Orchestrator ]
why_it_works: Novelty + Health + Author signals + Semantic relevance elevate hidden gems.
Diversity bonus avoids conceptual duplicates when embeddings are enabled.
Permissive licensing keeps integration safe and fast.
